Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The nexus of observation and modeling of methane emissions from inland water bodies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The impacts of climate and wetlands on each other are currently not well understood. While wetland plants consume carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, wetlands also produce methane, a powerful greenhouse gas that influences the global climate. Methane production and its movement within the soils of wetlands results from many simultaneous processes. Microorganisms living in wetland soils where there is no oxygen can produce methane. Methane, being lighter than air, works its way through the soil and can escape into the atmosphere. However, during transport through soils, specialized bacteria can consume methane if the local chemistry is favorable to that process. Additionally, plants can facilitate the movement of methane from soils to the atmosphere. This project will study the transport of methane through wetland vegetation and improve mathematical models of that process. This will be accomplished by developing new measurement techniques that can more accurately predict how much methane is transported through wetland plants. Results from this work will improve our general understanding of how wetlands function with respect to release of methane gas, a potent greenhouse gas important in climate modeling.

Plant transport is perhaps the most complex and least understood of the common methane pathways from the soil to the atmosphere. Moreover, wetlands are frequently comprised of a tight mosaic of land cover types. However, few models currently account for the effects of plant heterogeneity within the wetland on the total methane flux. Plants move methane both through their root aeration system, aerenchymous tissue, and through their xylem and stomata. It has been hypothesized that methane dissolved into the pore water at the plant root zone is mobilized by the plant as it transpires. However, the role of stomatally conducted methane is not clear and is almost always ignored by modern methane emission models. In this project, researchers will design and deploy novel chambers to quantify plant-mediated fluxes of methane from wetlands and use those data to parameterize a general model of the process. The study site for chamber deployment will be the Old Woman Creek National Estuary Research Reserve. These activities are part of a comprehensive measurement campaign involving traditional static chambers to measure diffusive fluxes through the water column, pore-water dialysis peepers, which provide a profile of methane concentrations in the soil, and an eddy-covariance tower, which will provide site level measurements of methane flux into the atmosphere. The plant hydrodynamics model, FETCH2, and a wetland methane model will be coupled to simulate the methane emitted through plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wetlands are the largest source of the greenhouse gas methane in the world. Despite this, there are large gaps in our scientific understanding of how methane is formed moves through the soil water and plants in the wetland, and how much of it is eventually emitted to the atmosphere. Methane is formed by soil microorganisms known as methanogens in low oxygen conditions and can then move to the atmosphere through a variety of pathways. One important and understudied methane pathway is through wetland plants. Typical methane flux measurements are performed by floating a hollow chamber on the wetland water surface and measuring the build-up of methane over time in the chamber space. This type of measurement is difficult to conduct over wetland plants, which can be up to two meters tall. Our study sought to measure and better understand how methane is transported through wetland plants by creating a new type of chamber that could enclose a full-grown wetland plant while floating on the wetland surface. The data from these measurements can be used to study the relationships between plants and methane emissions in wetlands, and to improve wetland models.

Intellectual merits: Through this grant, specialized chambers were created to float on a wetland surface and enclose plants for methane flux analysis. Plant fluxes were measured from May through September 2016 in Old Woman Creek National Estuarine Research Reserve in Huron, OH. We found that wetland plants are a very large source of methane to the atmosphere that are very rarely measured.

Morin then used the observations of fluxes from plants, along with other methane and CO2 fluxes, and other hydrological and meteorological measurements to set up the model ecosys to simulate Old Woman Creek.

Broader impacts: ecosys simulations of the Old Woman Creek site will set the stage for experimental modeling studies that would modernize the representation of transport of methane through plants.

This project has supported the publication of six peer reviewed journal articles and six conference presentations, with several other expected publications currently in production. In addition to the scientific accomplishments of the project, there were also several educational achievements. Four undergraduate and five additional graduate students participated in field and computational research as part of this grant, providing an enriching education hands-on scientific experience.

Morin and Rey-Sanchez also performed scientific demonstrations for the educational program Aqua Kids, a program that showcases science in aquatic environments for young adults. On the program, the researchers demonstrated common methods to detect gas fluxes between wetlands and the atmosphere. They also showed the large amount of methane formed in wetlands by capturing emissions and using the methane to creating a flare. This episode aired on October 12, 2016.
